{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3682900,"name":"Tom","username":"Zook","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zook/{size}/252720_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-17T17:00:32.384Z","cooked":"

Team 4276 moved into our school’s retired machine shop last summer. There were a LOT of machines and tools that got disappeared. But there was a lot of tools that were left behind in lockers and bins. Some have been adopted by our mentors, others have sat for a year taking up space.

After a year it is time to find them a new home. Either through scrappers or give aways. We do not want to hold onto this stuff and try to sell it on ebay or craigslist… even if that could net a fair amount of money. So, we’re offering the stuff up to anyone who can PHYSICALLY PICK UP the stuff. Cash donations welcome though

No shipping.
No item measurements.
No holds.

What you see in the photos is what is here. Morris tapers. Lathe Chucks. Chuck jaws. Lathe Dogs. Horizontal mill things. Massive endmills? I’m a physics teacher… cut me some slack.

IMG_05551428×1071 256 KB

IMG_05561428×1071 221 KB

IMG_05521428×1071 226 KB

IMG_05571428×1071 181 KB

IMG_05541428×1071 189 KB

IMG_05581428×1071 206 KB

IMG_05531428×1071 207 KB

We’re meeting next week on Wednesday 4-7pm, and Thursday 9am-12pm.
Interested in coming by? Send me a DM.

Wow, that must’ve been a hell of a shop. Aside from what you mention, there’s a bunch of lathe dogs, machine handwheels, endmills for horizontal mills, slitting (and roughing) saws for horizontal mills, and a bunch of old lantern-post-style lathe tool holders.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2025-07-17T17:13:51.192Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":469,"readers_count":468,"score":178.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":504363,"topic_slug":"socal-oc-area-free-old-machining-tools","display_username":"Zachary","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53819,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"ban the rev 40a breaker"},"post_url":"/t/socal-oc-area-free-old-machining-tools/504363/2","custom_user_title":"ban the rev 40a breaker","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3682954,"name":"Tom","username":"Zook","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zook/{size}/252720_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-17T18:41:14.333Z","cooked":"

It was. machineshop - Google Drive
Unfortunately most of the machines were in disrepair and hadn’t been used in years.

There might also be a large indexer for gear making (mentor is deciding if he wants it as a project) and one (or two) granite surface plates (12" across or so).

Can look at those if someone wanted to come by.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2025-07-17T18:42:35.248Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":423,"readers_count":422,"score":149.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":504363,"topic_slug":"socal-oc-area-free-old-machining-tools","display_username":"Tom","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1bTlDwj9NJSFf1lMsLsJHvgOlx6bx7YkG?usp=sharing","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":81}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14980,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4276 nice mentor"},"post_url":"/t/socal-oc-area-free-old-machining-tools/504363/3","custom_user_title":"4276 nice mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3682981,"name":"Zachary","username":"Zatack7","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zatack7/{size}/175437_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-17T19:06:09.843Z","cooked":"

Wow, a bunch of South Bends, a very nice prewar LeBlond (~90 years old), two beefy Cincinattis (one horizontal, one vertical), and those BPs (including one clone that has an 80s/90s CNC conversion kit). Everything, except for the two BP clones, was made in the US, down to the castings. Thank you for sharing!

Wow! I just want to annotate all of that And adopt a bunch. You had some BIG-ol machines there! That boring bar holder looks like it would take a 1.5" or 2" bar!

Man, I wish you weren’t diagonally across the country from me.

Good luck finding new homes for that stuff. I suspect a lot of it will get snagged.

Soooo many machines…

And WTF were they doing taking all those lathes apart? I see cross slides missing, compounds missing, and the whole carriage missing.

I would pay for some USPS flat rate boxes to adopt a couple of chucks… Far to far to drive.

Weldingrod1:

And WTF were they doing taking all those lathes apart? I see cross slides missing, compounds missing, and the whole carriage missing.

If I had to guess, cannibalization to keep a few running

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2025-07-18T21:08:01.249Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":267,"readers_count":266,"score":123.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":504363,"topic_slug":"socal-oc-area-free-old-machining-tools","display_username":"Zachary","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53819,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"ban the rev 40a breaker"},"post_url":"/t/socal-oc-area-free-old-machining-tools/504363/8","custom_user_title":"ban the rev 40a breaker","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3684320,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-18T21:39:34.827Z","cooked":"

The parts taken off are not things you break regularly Once in a “holey moley that was a close one!” kind of thing.

Makes my “old iron” heart bleed…

My first lathe was made on D-day! I replaced that with another WWII era (1940-1950) lathe bought from Mr. Stark of Stark Industries. Not Tony, though.

image889×477 25.9 KB

Weldingrod1:

The parts taken off are not things you break regularly

Oh, I know, but I think you underestimate decades of poor maintenance + untrained high schooler use.

What was your original one? (Currently, you have a Hardinge TL10, right?)

Yes, i have a TL-10. Quite the rare beast…
I started with a Sputh bend bought at a garage sale. The family has bought it new (grand parent level). They told me about putting a bar out the back of the headstock to run the ice cream freezer

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2025-07-18T22:20:39.544Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":235,"readers_count":234,"score":97.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":504363,"topic_slug":"socal-oc-area-free-old-machining-tools","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":53819,"username":"Zatack7","name":"Zachary","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zatack7/{size}/175437_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/socal-oc-area-free-old-machining-tools/504363/11","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3684346,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-18T22:26:42.499Z","cooked":"

I’m kinda amazed by three aspects here… anyone on CD has -ever- heard to a Hardinge TL-10 (the rarest one, IIRC), that I mentioned I have one, and someone remembered!

Maybe we need a cast iron thread

I feel like back in the 60s or 70s there must have been some kind of purchasing consortium or some other organized program to get these machines into schools in the Southern California area. I’ve seen the same “John Deer” green and yellow paint scheme on a lot of machines of the same era that came out of schools, which is weird to me. In fact, I rescued a 1962 Logan 11x24 lathe out of a school metal shop that looked identical to some of these, and I had bins of the same lamp post rocker tooling as well. I actually had Logan run the serial number on that lathe and it spent so eof it’s life in a factory in Los Angeles that made bandsaws in the 1960s, before going to the school. I don’t recall the name of that company.

Part of it would be the post-WWII/Korean War industrial winddown flooding the market with machine tools. As for the paint color, it’s likely that a tool dealer simply liked those colors a lot.

OK, so we didn’t move any material. And we didn’t scrap it either. But guess what? There’s more photos to show what you’re missing!

Lathe tooling! Some completely new (though a little oxidized)

IMG_05981428×1071 309 KB

Vices! The non-rusty one I cleaned up last winter. They all turn, just need some cleaning and oil. (ignore the old tailstock… unless you want it!)

IMG_05971428×1071 275 KB

Two parts bin units. Some of the bins come with bolts.

IMG_05991428×1071 225 KB

And finally, three dividing heads, with chucks. (1.125 flanged hex bearing shown for scale)

IMG_05951428×1071 195 KB

IMG_05941428×1071 176 KB

IMG_05961071×1428 230 KB

All turn. But all need a good cleaning. No index plates though. Two of them are a two-person lifting job.
